instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Client brought in device after device was liquid damaged. Noticed a build up of corrosion around <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> which appears to be where <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is created, and a blown Diode <DIODE>D6902</DIODE>.

First thing I did was give device an ultrasonic cleaning to remove the corrosion to get a better look. After which, I replaced <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> since it was severely blown. Images of before and after cleaning attached below. Device still would not boot, so I then applied alcohol around there area and injected 3V using a DCPS on to <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> and discovered that <CAPACITOR>C6906</CAPACITOR> was shorted. I have removed and replaced the shorted <CAPACITOR>C6906</CAPACITOR>, however device still does not boot.

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is sending 5V to <SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> to Pin 10 on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. (Is this voltage too high?)
Pin 2 on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> is being supplied 4.2V from <DIODE>D6902</DIODE>, however <DIODE>D6902</DIODE> is being supplied 5.2V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.
I believe <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> is bad and is pulling down voltage.
Pin 9 on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_FB</SIGNAL> is outputting 0.66V,
Pin 3 on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> <SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_LX</SIGNAL> Is outputting 2.2V.

USB-C Ammeter reads 5.2V with .0A consumption. I applied some more alcohol around <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> and injected 3V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with a .05A Consumption. I am currently waiting for some replacement <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> to arrive, but until then, any suggestions on what else I should be looking for? If <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> truly is bad, I found some replacements on DigiKey.com

Thank you in advance!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do not put the board in UC to clean so small area.
Scratch with fine tip and fiber glass pen.
Then clean with IPA and tootbrush.

I suppose corroded components around <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>.
Pay atention to <RESISTOR>R6910</RESISTOR>/11/12/13.
Also be sure <RESISTOR>R6908</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6907</CAPACITOR> are both OK.
Check traces and solders too.
If all OK, change <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah seeing where the corrosion was on this one, I don' think <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> issue even tho it is possible. Best for you to order some donors and replace what is nasty especially <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you for your input. I will make note of the UC for the future. The other components you mentioned test out fine, so it looks like I will be ordering a replacement <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>. Is it okay for the enable pin on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> to be 5v? I just want to make sure <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> isn't sending too high of a signal. Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: It took a while to get back to this board, however I did receive replacement <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> chips. After replacing the chip, the board still get 2.2v. However, if I remove <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> at the end of this circuit, the circuit gets 3.4v on Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR>. My thought process is that there is something pulling down voltage on Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR>. I then injected 3.3v into Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> which pulled at .015Amps and measured with Multi meter around  all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> which all received 3.3v.  I am now stumped and do not know where I should be looking.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> ok?? Did you replace any of the corroded components near <CHIP>U6903</CHIP>? My thoughts are something is definitely pulling down your 3v3 line like you said possibly a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip OR seeing where your liquid was it could even be the <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>. Voltage present at pin 10 of <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> with a good <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I removed <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> from board and measured 0.4 ohms. Schematic says <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> is 0 ohms. I did replace all corroded components except L6900, I do not have a replacement for this inductor in stock currently. I did replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> just to be sure there was no internal damage. Pin 10 on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> is currently receiving 4.9v from with <RESISTOR>R6923</RESISTOR> on board. I just received new stock of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> from Louis's online store recently, but have not replaced them yet.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 4.9 seems really really high to me.. sounds like possibly bad <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> or improperly soldered <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP>. Should be approx 3 volts on enable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I thought so too when I initially measured <CHIP>U6930</CHIP>. <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> originally was sending 5V to Pin 10 before I replaced it. Perhaps something around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is putting out too much power throughout this chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Just to rule out that there was not any internal issues with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, I went ahead a replaced all 4. Board is still getting 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. I then removed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> again and hooked up USB-C power supply and discovered that with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> removed, the enable Pin 10 on <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> receives 1.5v. From my understanding, it should be 0v with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> removed. I think some extra power is somehow in my enable line. I am looking in to this line currently.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2.2V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello,
Have you solved this problem?
I have 2 board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  with the exact same problem.
With the thermal camera I see heating <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> 43 Â° C and UB400 / UB300 50 Â° C
Enter the 0.30A on the boars
